title: APT38
descrption:
APT38 is a financially-motivated threat group that is backed by the North Korean regime. The group mainly targets banks and financial institutions and has targeted more than 16 organizations in at least 13 countries since at least 2014.[1]
North Korean group definitions are known to have significant overlap, and the name Lazarus Group is known to encompass a broad range of activity. Some organizations use the name Lazarus Group to refer to any activity attributed to North Korea.[2] Some organizations track North Korean clusters or groups such as Bluenoroff,[3] APT37, and APT38 separately, while other organizations may track some activity associated with those group names by the name Lazarus Group.

references.title: FireEye. (2018, October 03). APT38: Un-usual Suspects. Retrieved November 6, 2018.
US-CERT. (2017, June 13). Alert (TA17-164A) HIDDEN COBRA – North Korea’s DDoS Botnet Infrastructure. Retrieved July 13, 2017.
GReAT. (2017, April 3). Lazarus Under the Hood. Retrieved April 17, 2019.

related.Name: Clipboard Data
related.Use: APT38 used a Trojan called KEYLIME to collect data from the clipboard.[1]

related.Name: Command-Line Interface
related.Use: APT38 has used a command-line tunneler, NACHOCHEESE, to give them shell access to a victim’s machine.[1]

related.Name: Data Destruction
related.Use: APT38 has used a custom secure delete function to make deleted files unrecoverable.[1]

related.Name: Data Encrypted for Impact
related.Use: APT38 has used Hermes ransomware to encrypt files with AES256.[1]

related.Name: Disk Structure Wipe
related.Use: APT38 has used a custom MBR wiper named BOOTWRECK to render systems inoperable.[1]

related.Name: Drive-by Compromise
related.Use: APT38 has conducted watering holes schemes to gain initial access to victims.[1]

related.Name: File Deletion
related.Use: APT38 has used a utility called CLOSESHAVE that can securely delete a file from the system.[1]

related.Name: Indicator Removal on Host
related.Use: APT38 clears Window Event logs and Sysmon logs from the system.[1]

related.Name: Input Capture
related.Use: APT38 used a Trojan called KEYLIME to capture keystrokes from the victim’s machine.[1]

related.Name: Modify Registry
related.Use: APT38 uses a tool called CLEANTOAD that has the capability to modify Registry keys.[1]

related.Name: Process Discovery
related.Use: APT38 leveraged Sysmon to understand the processes, services in the organization.[1]

related.Name: Remote File Copy
related.Use: APT38 used a backdoor, NESTEGG, that has the capability to download and upload files to and from a victim’s machine.[1]

related.Name: Runtime Data Manipulation
related.Use: APT38 has used DYEPACK.FOX to manipulate PDF data as it is accessed to remove traces of fraudulent SWIFT transactions from the data displayed to the end user.[1]

related.Name: Software Packing
related.Use: APT38 has used several code packing methods such as Themida, Enigma, VMProtect, and Obsidium, to pack their implants.[1]

related.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
related.Use: APT38 used a backdoor, QUICKRIDE, to communicate to the C2 server over HTTP and HTTPS.[1]

related.Name: Stored Data Manipulation
related.Use: APT38 has used DYEPACK to create, delete, and alter records in databases used for SWIFT transactions.[1]

related.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
related.Use: APT38 installed a port monitoring tool, MAPMAKER, to print the active TCP connections on the local system.[1]

related.Name: System Shutdown/Reboot
related.Use: APT38 has used a custom MBR wiper named BOOTWRECK, which will initiate a system reboot after wiping the victim's MBR.[1]

related.Name: Transmitted Data Manipulation
related.Use: APT38 has used DYEPACK to manipulate SWIFT messages en route to a printer.[1]

related.Name: DarkComet
related.Techniques: Audio Capture, Clipboard Data, Command-Line Interface, Disabling Security Tools, Input Capture, Masquerading, Modify Registry, Process Discovery, Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder, Remote Desktop Protocol, Remote File Copy, Scripting, Software Packing, Standard Application Layer Protocol, System Information Discovery, System Owner/User Discovery, Video Capture

related.Name: Mimikatz
related.Techniques: Account Manipulation, Credential Dumping, Credentials in Files, DCShadow, Pass the Hash, Pass the Ticket, Private Keys, Security Support Provider, SID-History Injection

related.Name: Net
related.Techniques: Account Discovery, Create Account, Network Share Connection Removal, Network Share Discovery, Password Policy Discovery, Permission Groups Discovery, Remote System Discovery, Service Execution, System Network Connections Discovery, System Service Discovery, System Time Discovery, Windows Admin Shares
